item.title: Everything You Need To Know About Elden Ring Nightreign‘s DLC
item.content:encoded:
Elden Ring Nightreign’s first paid DLC, The Forsaken Hollow, is finally here. If it does it’s job, the new mini-expansion will bring fans back and give them new reasons to obsess over the surprisingly excellent multiplayer roguelike.

I’ve cleared my schedule and shamed my friends into joining me for whatever fresh surprises from FromSoftware await us. Here’s everything you need to know about the new content, including what’s in it, when it goes live, and the accompanying patch notes.

What time does Elden Ring Nightreign: The Forsaken Hollows go live?

The official release schedule of #ELDENRING #NIGHTREIGN The Forsaken Hollows is now available.

Learn how to access the content of The Forsaken Hollows here: https://t.co/YKcgUiynX1 pic.twitter.com/RJafPEq0dV

— ELDEN RING (@ELDENRING) December 2, 2025

This is the part that sucks. The global release times are staggered and consoles get the short end of the stick. The Forsaken Hollow launches December 3 at 6:00 p.m. ET on PC and December 4 at 12:00 a.m. ET. If you’re on Xbox Series X/S, you can pull the time zone trick to get in early, but it seems like everyone on PlayStation 5 and PS4 are out of luck.

I’m still holding out some small ray of hope that the DLC will magically unlock around 9:00 p.m. ET like most of Nightreign‘s free updates and weekly content rotations. That doesn’t seem to be the care this time around, however.

How do you access The Forsaken Hollows?

Just because you bought the $15 DLC doesn’t mean the content will automatically be active in your version of Nightreign. To actually access the two additional Nightfarer characters you’ll need to have first defeated Tricephalos, the game’s three-headed wolf Nightlord. After that, head to the Roundtable Hold, talk to the Iron Menial, and get the message from the Small Jar Merchant to unlock the new Scholar and Undertaker classes.

What about the new Shifting Earth event? To access that and the new Balancers boss fight, you’ll need to have completed the above steps and defeated a second Nightlord. With those conditions met you’ll head to a chapel that appears behind the Small Jar Merchant where you can activate the cataclysmic Shifting Earth event ‘The Great Hollows.’

What’s The Forsaken Hollows DLC adding to Nightreign?

There’s the Scholar, a new support class whose Character Skill is called Analyze and lets him debuff enemies by keeping them within a scoped view. His passive skill is Bagcraft which lets him hold more items. His Ultimate Art is called Communion and it links enemies so damaging one damages them all, while also doing the same for allies letting them share heals.

Then there’s Undertaker, a more aggressive melee class whose Character Skill is called Trance and gives her free stamina and bonus speed. Her Ultimate Art is Loathsome Hex which unleashes a flurry of attacks at whatever’s targeted. Her passive, Confluence, briefly gives her another free Ultimate Art any time an ally uses theirs.

The Forsaken Hollows DLC also adds the aforementioned Great Hollows Shifting Earth event, which isn’t just a repurposed section of the existing map but an entirely new area players will have to fly to with its own points of interest, ruins, and underground mazes. In addition to the new Balancers Nightlord, the DLC is bringing poison swamps to Limveld, fresh field bosses, and also entirely new weapons.

Most importantly, it should feel hard. “Whenever people who have played the main game extensively go into the DLC content, they’ll be able to have a bit of that feeling like they had when they first played Nightreign, where there’s still a bit that they’re trying to figure out,” director Junya Ishizaki promised. “[The Forsaken Hollows is] definitely a little bit harder, but it’s not ridiculous or anything like that, but that’s still within what we would consider to be a fair challenge.”

A new patch with no Nightfarer balance changes

Finally, the DLC arrives alongside the latest free update which is already live. It includes some small quality-of-life tweaks and a bunch of bug fixes, including for Raider’s Retaliate skill where it wouldn’t work properly and an ongoing issue where some Sites of Grace or Churches wouldn’t activate. Notably, however, there are no actual buffs or nerfs to the existing cast of characters. Maybe FromSoftware wants to see how Scholar and Undertaker compare before decided to rescale them.

Here are the full patch notes for Nightreign version 1.03:

New features

  • Added support for The Forsaken Hollows.
    • If you own the DLC The Forsaken Hollows, it will be displayed in the lower right corner of the title screen.
  • Added a display of the currently equipped relics in the Character Selection menu.
    • You can check the effects of equipped relics by toggling the display.
  • Added a feature to set names when registering Relics presets in the Relic Rites menu.
  • Set names can be changed in the All Presets section.
  • The order of presets for each character can now be changed in the All Presets section of the Relic Rites menu.
    • In the Relic Rites menu, you can change the order of presets (but not the order of the character themselves) in the All Relics section.
  • Added Deep Large Scenic Flatstone to the Collector Signboard shop.
  • The map’s layer display can now be toggled in the Results menu.
  • The relics equipped by each player can now be displayed in the Results menu.
    • Relics can only be displayed for sessions played in version 1.02 or later.
  • Players with a Personal Objective that requires defeating a specific target while Reliving a Remembrance can now embark on Expeditions with players whose Personal Objective does not require defeating a specific target.
    • Personal Objectives that do not require destroying the target will only appear for one player per Expedition.
  • The flask count will now be highlighted in the following situations:
  • When the flask count is at the maximum capacity,
  • When an enemy-induced effect that influences the flask is triggered.
  • The vertical position of the compass’ rune icon will now be displayed if the runes dropped upon death are significantly above or below the player character.
  • You can now highlight specific events that occur on a map layer that is on a different level from the character’s location in the map menu.
  • Adjusted the Dormant Power selection screen so that the HP gauge and other UI elements remain visible while the screen is displayed.
  • Adjusted the weapon lineup in Limveld’s shops.
  • Added Fire Pots to the shop inventory inside the Spirit Shetler.
  • The target-lock on enemies that are behind when the tombstone summoned by Raider’s Ultimate Art appears no longer gets released.

Balance Adjustments

In general, the trigger conditions of Relic effects that trigger with low HP, equipment passive effects, and special effects have been broadened.

Changes to Passive Effects and Special Effects

  • Added new Passive Effects:
    • Improved Melee Attack Power
    • Improved Dash Attacks
    • Improved Rolling Attacks
    • Increased the effect of the Passive Effect Improved Attack Power when Two-Handing.
    • Increased the effect of the Passive Effect Attack Up when Wielding Two Armaments.
    • Increased the effect of the Passive Effect Improved Chain Attack Finishers.
    • Increased the effect of the Passive Effect Improved Charge Attacks.
    • Increased the effect of the Passive Effect Improved Jump Attacks.
    • Increased the effect of the Passive Effect Improved Guard Counters.
    • Increased the effect of the Passive Effect Improved Skill Attack Power.
    • Increased the effect of the Passive Effect Physical Attack Up.
    • Broadened the trigger conditions and decreased the effectiveness of the Passive Effect Improved Damage Negation at Low HP.
    • Broadened the trigger conditions and decreased the effectiveness of the Talisman Blue-Feathered Branchsword.

Changes to Relic Effects

  • Increased the effect of Physical Attack Up.
  • Increased the effect of Improved Initial Standard Attack.
  • Increased the effect of Improved Critical Hits.
  • Increased the effect of Improved Guard Counters.
  • Increased the effect of Improved XXX Damage (excluding bow weapon types).
  • Increased the effect of Improved Attack Power with 3+ XX Equipped (excluding bow weapon types).
  • Broadened the trigger conditions and decreased the effectiveness of Improved Damage Negation at Low HP.

Other Changes

  • Reduced the FP consumption and increased the power of the Wrath of Gold Incantation.

Bug Fixes & improvements

  • Fixed a　bug in the Augur invasion event where the character would not be properly teleported to the battle area against Augur if the player was performing a critical hit at the time of the teleportation trigger.
  • Mitigated an issue where Sites of Grace or Churches would not activate and Leveling Up and Adding Charges to Flask could not be performed under some conditions.
  • Fixed a bug where the range of Night’s Tide differed from other players upon rejoining a session under some conditions.
  • Fixed a bug where Hammer weapons with the Prayerful Strike skill would not appear.
  • Fixed a bug where effects that heal or enhance allies did not apply to characters dodging or performing their Ultimate Art.
  • Fixed an issue where the weak points created by Ironeye’s skill Marking would appear for some players and not others under some conditions.
  • Fixed a bug where Raider’s Retaliate skill would be canceled and the character would flinch when receiving some enemy attacks that deal no damage while the skill was active.
  • Fixed a bug where affinity residues spawned by Recluse’s Elemental Defense passive ability would not appear when hit by some enemy attacks.
  • Fixed a bug where Stagger damage was not applied when parrying some enemy attacks with Executor.
  • Fixed a bug where the range of rolls to dodge some enemies’ darkness-imbued attacks was different than intended.
  • Fixed a bug in Depths Relics where the effect Greenspill Crystal Tear in possession at start of expedition did not appear.
  • Fixed a bug in the expedition menu where the gauge indicating the Deep of Night rating was not displayed when performing Reduce Depth, resulting in the subsequent gauge not reflecting the rate correctly.
  • Fixed a bug in the Relic Rites menu where the icon indicating placement in other Vessels was not displayed correctly.
  • Fixed a bug in the Dormant Power selection screen where the UI indicating rarity was not displayed on equipment and item icons.
  • Fixed an issue where sorting by FP Consumption in the Sparring Equipment menu and Visual Codex menu of the Sparring Grounds, when displaying the list of Sorceries and Incantations, did not work correctly.
  • Fixed a bug in the Results menu and Victor’s Record menu where the attributes added by Relics to each character’s weapons during an Expedition were not correctly reflected.
  • Fixed a bug in the Results menu where the special effects held by other players were not recorded beyond a certain number.
  • Fixed an issue where, if a session was disbanded immediately after a player left, the message at the title screen confirming the return to that session would keep appearing even after selecting OK.
  • Fixed some graphical rendering issues.
  • Fixed an issue where some sound effects did not play correctly.
  • Corrected some text.
  • Made several other performance improvements and bug fixes.

item.title: Final Fantasy VII’s Aerith Asks You To Stop Sending Actors Your ‘Smut’
item.content:encoded:
Every now and then, I remember when BioShock lead Ken Levine asked fans to stop sending him porn of Elizabeth from BioShock Infinite because it felt like seeing NSFW pictures of a daughter. Smut artists have only gotten bolder in the years since, because they’re sending this art directly to creators on various social media platforms. While some are down for it, Briana White, who voices Aerith in the Final Fantasy VII Remake trilogy, is not.

White responded to a video on X of Rei Ami, one of the vocalists from KPop Demon Hunters (and unabashed Fortnite fan), talking about how much smut she’d been exposed to of the titular demon-hunting trio. The voice of Zoey said it can be shocking but admitted to seeking some of it out herself. 

White responded, saying she doesn’t want people to “normalize” tagging actors in pornographic art of their characters, and that those who do this have “forgotten the meaning of the word ‘inappropriate’.”

“It’s really a shame when [voice actors] want to interact with the people who love the characters on social media, but just a few creeps ruin it for everyone,” White wrote.

“It is a matter of consent,” she continued elsewhere in the thread. “And it can be almost impossible to know what exactly is acceptable or not to an individual just from knowing their social media persona.”

I love smut as much as the next guy, but sending porn to actors unprompted is just harassment. It’s gotta be especially tough when these folks want to be part of the community and get face time with fans, but are met with this weirdo behavior. Draw your porn, write it, and post it on Archive of Our Own, but respect boundaries, folks. Everybody wins.

item.title: McDonald’s New Grinch Meal Finally Ports Shake Shake Fries To The U.S.
item.content:encoded:
McDonald’s released its new holiday meal, and there’s some good (and tasty) news for fans of the fast-food chain’s French fries. Thanks to the Grinch, McShaker fries are finally going to be available in the United States

On December 2, McDonald’s new limited-time-only Grinch Meal became available around the country. The Christmas-themed meal, which comes with a pair of limited-time festive holiday socks, is packaged in special bags featuring the Grinch and contains a medium drink, 10 McNuggets or a Big Mac, and some Dill Pickle “Grinch Salt” McShaker Fries. It’s that last item that has some fast-food lovers excited.

McShaker Fries appear to be a US version of Shake Shake Fries, a concept that has been around for many, many years in places like Hong Kong, the Philippines, and Taiwan. The fries have also popped up for limited runs in Canada, the United Kingdom, as well as India. Shake Shake Fries come packaged with a seasoning packet and a bag. You dump the fries and seasoning into the bag, close the top, and, well, as the name implies, shake it a few times to cover the fries in tasty dust. The concept has never made its way to the United States until now.

Early reactions to the Grinch’s dill pickle McShaker Fries are pretty positive, with people hoping McDonald’s keeps the concept around past Christmas and maybe even expands on it with some of the flavors found in other parts of the world. Personally, I’m not a pickle guy at all, so these fries sound awful, but I’m excited to see Shake Shake Fries brought over to the US, even if it is part of a Grinch-themed bundle.

Meanwhile, as you are already here and reading about limited-time fast-food meals, Burger King announced a new SpongeBob movie menu. This menu includes a slice of pie and a real Krabby Patty. It also comes in some delightful-looking SpongeBob-themed packaging that will no doubt be sold for $50 or more on eBay by the end of this week.

item.title: Metroid Prime 4: Beyond Might Be A Good Excuse To Upgrade To Switch 2
item.content:encoded:
If you’ve ever worn glasses, then you know this feeling well: Pop on your lenses and, bam, the world is in HD. That’s not a bad way to describe the difference between Metroid Prime 4: Beyond running on the original Switch vs. the new Switch 2.

Having shipped on both consoles, Metroid Prime 4 is a prime opportunity to get a sense of the clear technical differences between Nintendo’s newest console and its last-gen hardware. Sure, we know the Switch 2 is powerful, flexing its GPU muscles with Cyberpunk 2077 and some excellent ports of demanding open-world Ubisoft games. But Metroid is a first-party exclusive, so it’s a great opportunity to see the differences when just Nintendo’s hardware is the target.

Read More: Ubisoft’s Becoming The King Of Switch 2 Ports

The result? The Switch 2 damn sure renders a pretty picture for our gal Samus’ latest adventure. That said, the OG Switch, while it has a softer image, still looks and runs well enough. The load times though…yeesh. This comparison video from ElAnalistaDeBits shows the differences in motion:

Switch 2 has a crisper image, and performance mode looks slick

Switch 2 on both quality and performance modes shows a clear advantage when it comes to a higher resolution and clearer images. The performance mode is a touch softer, but you’re trading a bit of fidelity for 120 frames per second. And if you don’t think a framerate that high is worth it, as a former skeptic of anything higher than 60 FPS being worthwhile, I must tell you that you’re wrong.

Switch 1 ain’t nothin’ to sneeze at…but you’re gonna wanna grab a coffee while it loads

If you’re like me and all you have laying around is an original Switch, Metroid Prime 4 doesn’t look too terrible. And it runs at 60 FPS, which is swell. But perhaps the worst part of running the game on a classic Switch is you’ll be waiting a long time for it to load. The comparison video above shows a loading sequence that only takes the Switch 2 a mere 24 seconds, while the OG console loads in at over a minute and four seconds. Reminds me of playing The Witcher 3 on PS4 (still had a great time! But man did I do a lotta waiting).

If you’re looking for an excuse to upgrade, Metroid might just be it

Sometimes ya gotta make due with the hardware you have. But if you’ve got some cash burning a hole in your pocket and you’re ready to step into Nintendo’s next generation, and you love Metroid, it seems like the Switch 2 version might make the upgrade worth it. As Nintendo Life puts it in their review of Beyond, once you see the “next-gen” version in motion, it’s hard to go back:

Playing this on Switch 1 when docked feels fine enough, but that crispness, that pop, that ludicrously intricate, high-contrast detail, it’s just a bit fuzzy and pixelly by comparison. I personally feel it’s almost the direct antithesis to Pokémon Legends Z-A, which actually felt as though the art style was more cohesive on the weaker platform. Textures have taken an understandable hit, and models that are further away can look quite smeary, but overall the game still looks good. I just can’t help but compare it unfavourably to Switch 2.

Again, given that the original console runs the game at 60 frames per second, I’d wager the experience of playing the game will still feel good enough, even if it’s a little soft compared to what the latest hardware can deliver. But what are upgrades for if we’re not getting prettier pixels? If you do snag Metroid for the OG Switch and end up acquiring a Switch 2 down the line, you can also upgrade the Switch 1 version to the prettier Switch 2 version for an extra 10 bucks.

item.title: WD 5TB My Passport Falls to $0.02 per GB as Amazon Goes No-Margin on Storage Deals Post Cyber Monday
item.content:encoded:
We’ve been banging the drum for deals on reliable, large-capacity portable HDDs for a long time now. Honestly, going without one is really like doing a high-wire act without a net, because having only the one copy of your most sensitive and essential files that lives on your laptop or desktop leaves you one mishap away from losing them forever.

Cyber Week’s one of the best opportunities to get protection for your irreplaceable data, and one of the best deals still on the board is this one at Amazon on the 5TB version of the WD My Passport external hard drive, which is just $121. That’s a 16% drop from the regular $145, and it’s a stellar price for an external drive with this sort of capacity and reliability from a trusted brand like Western Digital — in fact, it’s the world’s first 5TB 2.5-inch portable hard drive. Be sure to click the black model of this palm-sized drive — inexplicably, the blue and red ones are still running at full price.

See at Amazon

Ransomware Protection

External HDDs tend to be fairly static devices, aside from shrinking in physical size and growing in capacity. Beyond that, the features have remained mostly the same. Except now, WD has added software to the My Passport HDD that includes robust protection against the ever-growing and constantly evolving threat of ransomware.

A virus or malware can get into not only your laptop or desktop but also into its peripheral devices, including your portable hard drive. Once there it can install ransomware, which locks you out of your files until you pay a ransom to the hacker. The Acronis True Image for Western Digital software preloaded on the My Passport HDD not only helps you schedule automatic backups, it helps protect your entire system from ransomware, and also allows you to password-protect and give your files 256-bit AES encryption.

Smaller and Faster

The WD My Passport HDD comes preformatted for Windows, but can easily be reformatted for use with Macs without losing any of its protective features. WD’s given it a slimming-down from its previous models too – this streamlined version of the My Passport is just 3.21 by 4.33 inches, and exceedingly slim, so you can fit up to 5TB of your most essential files in your pocket to take with you anywhere, and its footprint at your desktop or work station is virtually nil.

It connects via USB-A 3.0, but it’s also compatible with USB-A 2.0 devices, and the 5Gbps data transfer speed allows you to move files to or from your PC or Mac laptop or desktop computers quickly and easily. It can be set up for automatic backups, and is also drag-and-drop ready from the time you connect it.

Those digital photos and videos on your computer need protection in the form of a large-capacity, fast, ultra-reliable backup drive that fits in your pocket and comes with advanced protection. So do your financial records and other sensitive personal information. The WD My Passport 5TB portable external hard drive — the world’s first 5TB 2.5-inch drive — checks all those boxes, and it’s a great Cyber Week find at just $121 at Amazon.

item.title: Every New Pokémon Legends: Z-A, DLC Announcement Has Flygon Fans Crashing Out
item.content:encoded:
I waited over a decade for Raichu to get a Mega Evolution, so I sympathize with anyone who has a beloved Pokémon they’re hoping might get one in Pokémon Legends: Z-A’s upcoming Mega Dimension DLC. Now that my favorite electric rat has not just one, but two Mega Evolutions, the title for “most oppressed Pokémon fan waiting for a Mega Evolution” now goes to the Flygon stans, and they’re really going through it.

Flygon was first introduced in Pokémon Ruby and Sapphire, and the dragon/ground-type beast has been a fan favorite ever since. It’s easy to see why. The insectoid dragon oozes cool while also being kinda cute in that uniquely Pokémon kind of way. He is very “friend-shaped” and also a powerhouse in battle, giving him all the makings of a generation of fans’ favorite critter. 

Flygon was famously one of the Pokémon originally slated to get a Mega Evolution in the 3DS era when the mechanic was introduced, only for the idea to later get scrapped because Game Freak couldn’t nail down the design. With Legends: Z-A bringing back Mega Evolution and introducing new forms for old monsters, Flygon fans have been crossing all their fingers hoping that the long-lost Mega might finally make its grand debut. 

But every time Game Freak announces a new Mega Evolution that isn’t for Flygon, the light continues to dwindle from their eyes.

Flygon vendo Lucario ganhar a segunda mega: pic.twitter.com/I6Emz5f7hw

— Vida de Treinador (@VidaDeTreinador) December 2, 2025

Mega flygon está oficialmente MORTO
Não vai ter nem na DLC pic.twitter.com/ENLLqkB9km

— rayquaza, pokemon até namorar #Chronoverso (@azarco91) October 13, 2025

What makes this even more painful is that there was a brief flicker of hope in the first trailer for the Mega Dimension DLC, which showed a portal filled with Mega Stones, one of which appeared to have Flygon’s color scheme, but thus far, no Mega has materialized in the DLC’s promotion.

Unfortunately, with each new reveal seemingly confirming previous leaks that don’t include Mega Flygon, it seems like the dream is well and truly dead. Unless Game Freak brings back Mega Evolutions in another decade? Maybe the third time will be the charm. I don’t know if Flygon fans can handle another big setback

item.title: Toshiba 50″ Smart Fire TV Goes Into Clearance Mode at 51% Off, Amazon’s Deeper Post–Black Friday Discount Move
item.content:encoded:
Entertainment upgrades don’t have to blow your budget; if you know where to look. The biggest shopping events of the year – aka Cyber Monday and Black Friday – are officially behind us, but not all deals have expired. We’re still spotting plenty of great discounts across a range of categories, so whether you missed grabbing a new TV or a tech gadget, there’s still a chance to save.

Right now, Amazon is offering an unbelievable 51% discount on the 50-inch Toshiba Class C350 Series LED 4K smart Fire TV. It typically sits at $350, but this discount brings its price down to just $170. The offer is open to all shoppers, meaning both Prime and non-Prime members can snap it up. Even better, there are no delivery charges to worry about, so you’re saving a bit on that front, too. There’s a catch, though. The discount is selling out fast, so there’s not a lot of time left to save. Lingering deals such as this one are hardly around for a couple of days before getting back to their original price. If you’ve been looking to bag a smart screen for less, now is the time to act.

See at Amazon

Brilliant Visuals

The 50-inch size isn’t massive, but also not too small. It’s ideal for bedrooms, smaller living areas, and anyone who is not a fan of screens taking up an entire wall. Toshiba packs it with its revolutionary REGZA Engine ZR, which uses precise analyzing technology. The Super Contrast Booster maximizes the depth of picture color, keeping it as accurate as possible. This is paired with the brand’s exceptional AI upscaling technology, which, instead of replicating every pixel, detects the colors of neighboring pixels. It then considers the detailed texture of the real sight to decide a color for each pixel. Translation? You’ll enjoy every moment on the screen with the clarity of 4K quality.

Blur is actively reduced during fast-paced sequences with Ultimate Motion. There’s also a Game mode, which supports a whole bunch of gaming features, such as ALLM (Auto Low Latency Mode), VRR (Variable Refresh Rate), and eARC. Combine this mode with Ultimate Motion, and you’ll be able to play your favorite titles in a much smoother manner; great for those upcoming holiday game nights. Visuals are only part of the experience, though. Sound matters just as much, and for that, the TV supports Dolby Atmos for a realistic, room-filling audio. You won’t just get to see your favorite scenes coming to life; you’ll experience them in a realistic way.

Fire TV support brings all your favorite content and streaming platforms to a single place, so you’re never going to be out of stuff to watch. Think Netflix, Prime Video, Hulu, Disney, Peacock, and more. Most of these require subscriptions, but if you’re not a fan of that, you can always access plenty of free, ad-supported platforms through it just as well.

To wrap it up, if you’ve been looking to grab a brand new display without shelling out big bucks, now is a good time to make the move. This deal takes a whopping $180 off its retail price, bringing it down to a much more affordable range. Just make sure to grab yours fast, as discounts such as this one don’t last too long.
